questions.question:
Question 1: Which of the following findings would you not expect in a patient diagnosed with small-vessel 
vasculitis?
questions.explanation:
Ischemic optic neuropathy associated with giant cell arteritis (large vessel vasculitis) can present 
as visual loss. Small vessel vasculitis is the inflammation of arterioles, capillaries, or venules. It starts with 
nonspecific symptoms like fever, fatigue, and arthralgia. Since it mainly affects the small vessels 
and capillaries present in the lungs, kidney, and skin, the majority of the patients will have: • Hemoptysis • Glomerulonephritis (hematuria, proteinuria) • Palpable purpura

questions.question:
Question 2: Which of the following structures is most commonly involved in cutaneous small-vessel 
vasculitis?
questions.explanation:
The structure most commonly involved in cutaneous small-vessel vasculitis is postcapillary 
venules. Cutaneous small-vessel vasculitis is defined as vasculitis which is limited to the small vessels of 
the skin. There is no systemic vasculitis and glomerulonephritis. It most commonly affects 
postcapillary venules. It is characterized by the presence of leukocytoclasis (presence of neutrophil debris in and around 
the blood vessels).

questions.question:
Question 3: A patient presents with cutaneous vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, and peripheral neuropathy. 
Which investigation should be performed next to help you diagnose the condition?
questions.explanation:
The presence of cutaneous vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, and peripheral neuropathy are 
suggestive of small-vessel vasculitis. Investigating for ANCA (antineutrophil cytoplasmic 
antibodies) should be the next step to aid in diagnosis. Small Vessel Vasculitis/ ANCA- associated Vasculitis 466

questions.question: Question 4: Which is the most common form of vasculitis associated with connective tissue disorders?
questions.explanation:
The most common form of vasculitis associated with connective tissue disorders is small-vessel 
venulitis. Connective tissue disorders that can cause vasculitis are: • Systemic lupus erythematosus • Rheumatoid arthritis • Relapsing polychondritis • Sjögren's syndrome

questions.question:
Question 5: A pathology resident is examining biopsy specimens of patients with clinical features of 
vasculitis. In which of the following conditions would he report granulomatous inflammation 
of the vessels?
questions.explanation:
Biopsy findings of giant cell arteritis, Churg-Strauss syndrome, and Takayasu arteritis show 
granulomatous inflammation of vessels as they are granulomatous vasculitis. The vasculitis diseases can be classified as: Granulomatous vasculitis

questions.question:
Question 6: A 45-year-old woman presents with pain over the forehead aggravated on bending and 
occasional hemoptysis. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated ESR and red cell casts in the 
urine. Her serology is positive for cANCA. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
467 
Sold by @itachibot The given clinical scenario with cANCA positivity is suggestive of granulomatosis with polyangiitis 
(Wegener's granulomatosis). It is characterized by the involvement of the upper respiratory tract 
(sinusitis), lower respiratory tract (occasional hemoptysis), and kidneys (red cell casts). It is a granulomatous, necrotizing vasculitis of the small vessels that mainly affects: • Upper respiratory tract- presenting with sinusitis, otitis media, and nasal septal perforation. • Lower respiratory tract- presenting with hemoptysis. • Kidney (glomerulonephritis)- presenting with proteinuria, hematuria, and hypertension. Apart from these organs, the disease can also affect the eye and skin. Skin lesions present as 
palpable purpura or subcutaneous nodules. Laboratory investigations show anemia, leucocytosis, 
elevated ESR, and ANCA positivity. Options A and C: In Goodpasture's syndrome and microscopic polyangiitis, the symptoms of 
upper respiratory tract involvement are very rare. Option D: Henoch-Schonlein purpura is commonly seen in children. It presents with palpable 
purpura, joint pain, abdominal pain, and glomerulonephritis.

questions.question:
Question 7: A patient who presented with skin rashes, otitis media and hematuria has been diagnosed 
with granulomatosis with polyangiitis. Which of the following drugs would you not use in the 
management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Abatacept is a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) used in the treatment of 
rheumatoid arthritis. Important drugs used in the management of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's 
granulomatosis) are: • Cyclophosphamide • Rituximab (anti CD20 antibody) • Glucocorticoids • Methotrexate

questions.question:
Question 8: A middle-aged woman presents with hemoptysis, proteinuria, and the clinical presentation 
given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario showing saddle nose deformity along with hemoptysis, and proteinuria 
is suggestive of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis). Involvement of upper respiratory tract in granulomatosis with polyangiitis manifests as: • Paranasal sinusitis, serous otitis media • Nasal ulcers, purulent or bloody nasal discharge • Nasal perforation leading to the destruction of septum and saddle nose deformity • Subglottic tracheal stenosis 468 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following is not a feature associated with Wegener's granulomatosis?
questions.explanation:
Wegener's granulomatosis is associated with necrotizing vasculitis. Wegener's granulomatosis predominantly affects the small blood vessels of the upper respiratory 
tract, lungs, and kidneys. Lung involvement will show multiple, bilateral cavitating nodules and 
pulmonary infiltrates on chest X-ray. The radiograph below shows cavitating nodules in a patient with granulomatosis with polyangiitis 
(Wegener's granulomatosis). Renal involvement initially appears as focal or segmental glomerulonephritis on biopsy. If left 
untreated, it can lead to rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN). Patients with Wegener's 
granulomatosis have an increased incidence of venous thrombosis, like deep vein thrombosis and 
pulmonary embolism. The diagnosis is confirmed by the presence of necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis on biopsy. 
This finding is commonly seen in the tissues obtained from lungs, skin, upper airways, and rarely 
kidneys.

questions.question:
Question 10: A 57-year-old man presented with complaints of fever, weight loss, and hemoptysis. His 
serology was positive for pANCA and biopsy showed small vessel vasculitis with neutrophil 
infiltration. Which of the following is a feature associated with his condition? 463 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical presentation along with pANCA positivity and biopsy findings of 
leukocytoclastic (neutrophil infiltration) vasculitis point towards a diagnosis of microscopic 
polyangiitis. It is associated with fibrinoid necrosis. Microscopic polyangiitis, also known as hypersensitivity vasculitis, causes segmental fibrinoid 
necrosis of small arterioles and venules. It is associated with neutrophil infiltration, and hence 
also called leukocytoclastic vasculitis. Histopathology of the affected tissue will show necrotizing vasculitis of arterioles, venules, and 
capillaries without any granulomas. It is caused by ANCA (antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies) 
and is not mediated by the immune complex. It primarily affects the kidneys and lungs. 469 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: Which of the following features is not useful to distinguish between microscopic polyangiitis 
and granulomatosis with polyangiitis?
questions.explanation:
Both microscopic polyangiitis and granulomatosis with polyangiitis are associated with 
necrotizing vasculitis. Hence, this feature is not useful to distinguish between them.

questions.question:
Question 12: A triad of skin lesions, asymmetric mononeuritis multiplex and eosinophilia is seen in which 
of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
A triad of skin lesions, asymmetric mononeuritis multiplex, and eosinophilia is seen in Churg–
Strauss syndrome (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis). It is a necrotizing vasculitis of the small-to-medium-sized vessels and in order to be diagnosed 
with Churg-Strauss, a patient should have evidence of asthma, peripheral blood and tissue 
eosinophilia (>1000 cells/L), extravascular granuloma formation and clinical features 
consistent with vasculitis. Common presenting symptoms of this condition are lower respiratory tract symptoms such as 
severe attacks of asthma, upper respiratory tract symptoms such as allergic rhinitis, sinusitis, and 
nasal polyps, mono neuritis multiplex (a type of peripheral neuropathy affecting at least two 
nerves) which presents with a complaint of pain, numbness, or weakness in the affected areas and 
skin lesions like palpable purpura and subcutaneous nodules. Renal involvement is less common and less severe than other small vessel vasculitis. P-ANCA antibodies are present in Churg Strauss syndrome. • Severe attacks of asthma • Mononeuritis multiplex: a type of peripheral neuropathy affecting at least two nerves. Patients 
will complain of pain, numbness, or weakness in the affected areas. • Skin lesions like palpable purpura and subcutaneous nodules. Glucocorticoids show effective responses in these patients. Other drugs that have been tried are 
mepolizumab and rituximab. For fulminant multisystem disease, daily cyclophosphamide with prednisolone followed by 
azathioprine or methotrexate is used. Option A: Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis presents with palpable purpura, arthralgia, neuropathy, 
and glomerulonephritis. It is most commonly associated with Hepatitis C. Option B: Polyarteritis nodosa can also present with mononeuritis multiplex and skin lesions, but 
they do not have eosinophilia, it has predominant neutrophilia. Option D: Giant cell arteritis manifests with the cardinal symptom of headache localized to the 
temporal region. Common symptoms include headache, polymyalgia rheumatica , jaw 
claudication, fever, and decrease in body weight. Laboratory results show increased ESR, CRP 
levels, normochromic or mildly hypochromic anemia. 470 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 13: A 47-year-old housewife presented with recurrent attacks of asthma and pain and numbness 
along the distribution of the median and ulnar nerve. Her serology was positive for pANCA. 
Further evaluation is unlikely to reveal which of the following findings?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of asthma, mononeuritis multiplex, and pANCA positivity is suggestive 
of Churg-Strauss syndrome (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis). It affects small to 
medium-sized arteries. Laboratory investigations will show peripheral blood eosinophilia. Some patients may be positive 
for pANCA (antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies). Histopathology will show the presence 
of necrotizing vasculitis, tissue eosinophilia, and extravascular granulomas. Histopathology of ANCA associated vasculitides can be remembered as: • Microscopic polyangiitis: necrotizing vasculitis • Wegener's granulomatosis: necrotizing vasculitis with granulomas • Churg Strauss syndrome: necrotizing vasculitis with extravascular granulomas and eosinophilia

questions.question:
Question 14: 464 
Sold by @itachibot A 6-year-old boy presents to the ER with colicky abdominal pain. His mother tells you that he 
refuses to walk due to knee pain. On examination, palpable purpura is noted. What is the 
most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical presentation of palpable purpura, colicky abdominal pain, and arthritis, point 
towards a diagnosis of Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP) also known as IgA vasculitis. It is a small vessel vasculitis that occurs due to IgA immune complex deposition within the wall of 
the blood vessels. It is commonly seen in children and is characterized by: • Palpable purpura without thrombocytopenia and coagulopathy. • Arthralgia- commonly affecting hip, knee, or ankle joints. • Abdominal pain • Glomerulonephritis: proteinuria, microscopic hematuria, RBC casts in urine. The skin biopsy will show small vessel vasculitis, with IgA and C3 deposition in the affected 
organs by immunofluorescence. Option B: Hemolytic uremic syndrome is characterized by a triad of microangiopathic hemolytic 
anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury. Option C: Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is characterized by fever of at least 2 weeks duration 
associated with arthritis, evanescent erythematous rash, hepatosplenomegaly, generalized 
lymphadenopathy, and serositis. Option D: Patients with IgA nephropathy or Berger's disease present with gross hematuria, often 
associated with a preceding or ongoing viral infection of the upper respiratory tract 
(synpharyngitic presentation).

questions.question:
Question 15: Cryoglobulinemia is associated with  
.
questions.explanation:
Cryoglobulinemia is associated with hepatitis C infection. 471 
Sold by @itachibot Following Hepatitis C infection, there is an aberrant immune response leading to an immune 
complex formation containing hepatitis C antigens, polyclonal IgG specific to Hepatitis C, and 
monoclonal IgM rheumatoid factor, which triggers an inflammatory cascade results in 
Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. Cryoglobulins are the immunoglobulins that precipitate at temperatures less than 37°C, the 
presence of these cryoglobulins in serum leads to Cryoglobulinemia, which is characterized by 
cutaneous vasculitis, palpable purpura, arthritis, peripheral neuropathy, and glomerulonephritis. Important conditions associated with cryoglobulinemia are: • Hepatitis C • Multiple myeloma • Connective tissue disorders • Lymphoproliferative disorders 472
